title: My Child Learns Soroban But Won't Practice – What Now?
description: They understand soroban. They can do it. They just won't practice willingly. Here's how to handle practice resistance.

content.intro: My daughter likes soroban – she feels proud when she solves problems. But getting her to sit down and practice? It's a daily battle. "Not now." "Later." "I already know this." Sound familiar?

items: **Repetition feels boring:** Same types of problems daily
**Other things are more fun:** Games, videos, playing
**Effort vs. reward:** "I can already do this, why more?"
**Autonomy:** Being told to do something triggers resistance

sections.text: Instead of "practice soroban," I say "do 5 problems." Just 5. It takes 3 minutes. She can't reasonably argue against 3 minutes. Most days, she keeps going after the 5.
Soroban happens after breakfast, before any screen time. It's not a question of "if" but "when." Screen time is the reward. No practice = no screens. Simple, consistent.
"Do you want practice mode or game mode today?" Giving choice reduces resistance. She feels in control even though practice is happening either way.
We have a wall calendar where she puts a star for each day she practices. She's proud of her streak. Missing a day means breaking the chain – she cares about that.
The key insight: Remove the daily decision. Make it automatic, non-negotiable, but small enough to be painless.
I stopped calling it "practice" (boring) and started calling it "brain training" (cool) or "your math game" (fun). Words matter. Same activity, different framing.

faq.question: Should I pay my child to practice?
faq.answer: Generally not per session – it creates transactional expectations. Weekly allowance tied to responsibilities (including practice) is okay.

faq.question: What if 5 problems is too few?
faq.answer: 5 is the minimum. Most kids do more once they start. And 5 daily beats 0 from resistance. Consistency over volume.

faq.question: My child argues no matter what. Help!
faq.answer: Stop arguing back. State the expectation, walk away. "Soroban before screens. Let me know when you're done." Don't engage in debate.

cta.text: Our app's short sessions are designed for real kids with limited patience.
